coredata.dc:title: Ru/Nb co-doped perovskite anode: Achieving good coking resistance in hydrocarbon fuels via core-shell nanocatalysts exsolution
coredata.dc:creator: Qin, Mingxia
Xiao, Yu
Yang, Hongyu
Tan, Ting
Wang, Ziming
Fan, Xinming
Yang, Chenghao
coredata.dc:description: Ru/Nb co-doped (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.8Ru0.1Nb0.1O3-δ (PSFRN) cubic perovskite oxide was fabricated and used as the solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode material. After treated in wet H2 at 900 °C for 2 h, the PSFRN was partially transformed into Ruddlesden-Popper (RP) layered perovskite PrSrFe0.8Ru0.1Nb0.1O4+δ (RP-PSFRN), and Fe0.7Ru0.3 alloy-FeO x oxide (FRA@FO) core-shell nanoparticles were in-situ exsolved on the reduced-PSFRN (R-PSFRN) substrate surface. The phase transition and the exsolution of the nanoparticles were investigated using X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscope and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Modified by the in-situ exsolved FRA@FO core-shell nanoparticles, the R-PSFRN anode material showed high catalytic activity for hydrogen and hydrocarbon fuels. The power density of SOFC reached 0.683 and 0.537 W cm−2 with wet H2 and C3H8 as fuel at 800 °C, respectively. Moreover, the SOFC showed a stable output under a constant current load of 0.15 A cm−2 in C3H8, demonstrating a high resistance to carbon deposition and coking.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Perovskite anode
In-situ exsolution
Core-shell nanoparticles
Hydrocarbon fuel

(a) SEM and (b, c) TEM images of as-prepared PSFRN. (d) SEM and (e, f) TEM images of R-PSFRN.

(a) Electrical conductivity of R-PSFRN and (b) R-PSF samples in wet H2 at different temperatures and (c) corresponding conductivity Arrhenius plots. (d) Impedance spectra of the symmetric cell with R-PSFRN-GDC composite electrodes (Fitted results are showed as the continuous lines).

(f, h) Microstructure images of the porous R-PSFRN-GDC anode after stability test.

head.ce:title: Ru/Nb co-doped perovskite anode: Achieving good coking resistance in hydrocarbon fuels via core-shell nanocatalysts exsolution

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: M. Qin and Y. Xiao contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Ru/Nb co-doped (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.8Ru0.1Nb0.1O3-δ (PSFRN) cubic perovskite oxide was fabricated and used as the solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anode material. After treated in wet H2 at 900 °C for 2 h, the PSFRN was partially transformed into Ruddlesden-Popper (RP) layered perovskite PrSrFe0.8Ru0.1Nb0.1O4+δ (RP-PSFRN), and Fe0.7Ru0.3 alloy-FeO x oxide (FRA@FO) core-shell nanoparticles were in-situ exsolved on the reduced-PSFRN (R-PSFRN) substrate surface. The phase transition and the exsolution of the nanoparticles were investigated using X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscope and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Modified by the in-situ exsolved FRA@FO core-shell nanoparticles, the R-PSFRN anode material showed high catalytic activity for hydrogen and hydrocarbon fuels. The power density of SOFC reached 0.683 and 0.537 W cm−2 with wet H2 and C3H8 as fuel at 800 °C, respectively. Moreover, the SOFC showed a stable output under a constant current load of 0.15 A cm−2 in C3H8, demonstrating a high resistance to carbon deposition and coking.

ce:section.ce:para: High performance solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) is considered a promising green energy technology due to its environmental friendly and considerable energy conversion efficiency [1]. At present, fossil energy still accounts for 70–90 % of the world's energy consumption and will remain a main part of the energy industry for a long time in the future. Based on this background, a large number of studies have been carried out to explore hydrocarbon as the alternative fuels to SOFC, including syngas, natural gas, propane, ethanol, etc. These hydrocarbon fuels have the advantages of low generation cost and convenient transportation, which is of great significance to the application of SOFC. Nevertheless, one of the major challenges for direct conversion of hydrocarbon in SOFC is catalytic deactivation due to carbon deposition and coking of the anode. Although Ni is a widely used anode material in SOFC and exhibits excellent catalytic performance in H2, it is no longer effective in hydrocarbon fuels due to carbon deposition at operating temperatures [2]. The DFT studies of the carbon formation on Ni catalyst found that Ni (211) bonds carbon strongly and eventually produces graphite [3], which may occupy the activation sites and hinders the catalytic reaction. Based on this, a large number of studies were devoted to minimizing carbon composition and coking to improve the applicability of anodes to hydrocarbon fuels [4]. One of the significance strategies was to develop perovskite-based anode. Perovskite oxides generally exhibit the properties of mixed ion-electron conduction (MIEC), which can broaden the three-phase boundary (TPB) of electrochemical reactions. The carbon deposition can be alleviated by optimizing the concentration and mobility of oxygen vacancies in the perovskite oxides. For example, Tao etc. used Mn partial substitution of Cr in the La0.75Sr0.25CrO3 to produce a large amount of oxygen vacancies, increasing the oxygen-ion conductivity and suppressing the carbon deposition in methane [5]. However, these alternative perovskite-based anodes were generally difficult to obtain desirable catalytic properties.

In-situ exsolution is a novel modification method for perovskite-based anodes. Doping B-sites with reducible transition elements, surface nanoparticles modified catalysts can be obtained by in-situ exsolution method: the reducible elements in the B-sites of host perovskite are readily precipitated to the matrix surface under reducing atmosphere [6–9]. Thermodynamically, the exsolution of B-site elements is a heterogeneous process which driven by the Gibbs free energy change between metal ions in host oxide lattices and surface metal nanoparticles. With the escape of O2− from lattice oxygen sites under the reducing atmosphere, B sites cations with low reduction stability precipitate from the lattice and form metal particles on the surface, which may be accompanied by phase decomposition and surface reconstruction [10]. The metal nanoparticles on the perovskite oxide surface act as active centers for electrochemical catalysis, enhancing the catalytic activity and anti-coking properties for hydrocarbon fuels. Furthermore, when some perovskite oxides been treated in reducing atmosphere, the exsolved B site elements will form the core-shell nanoparticles on the surface [11]. Hou etc. found that the nanoparticles with Co0.94Fe0.06 core and (Co, Fe)3O4 shell showed an excellent performance for hydrocarbon oxidation [9]. The shells of the exsolved nanoparticles can not only enhance the resistance to carbon deposition, but also provide a pathway for oxygen ions and broaden the TPB [12,13].

In this work, we prepared Ru/Nb co-doped (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.8Ru0.1Nb0.1O3-δ (PSFRN) cubic perovskite oxides through the glycine nitrate combustion (GNC) method. The introduction of redox stable cations Nb5+ was aimed to stabilize the crystal structure and suppress the complete decomposition of perovskite oxide in the high temperature reduction process [14]. After being treated in wet H2 at 900 °C for 2 h, large amount of core-shell structure Fe0.7Ru0.3-FeO x (FRA@FO) nanoparticles were formed on the reduced-PSFRN (R-PSFRN) surface. The single cells based on La0.8Sr0.2Ga0.83Mg0.17O3-δ (LSGM) electrolyte showed a peak power density of 0.683 and 0.537 W cm−2 at 800 °C under wet H2 and C3H8 at 800 °C, respectively. In addition, no clear carbon deposition was found on the anode after the stability test for 100 h in wet C3H8. This work provided a significant insight into the design of high performance metal/oxide exsolution at on perovskite-type ferrite based anode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of catalyst and cell fabrication
ce:section.ce:para: (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.8Ru0.1Nb0.1O3-δ (PSFRN) powder was prepared by the glycine nitrate combustion (GNC) method. Firstly, stoichiometric amount of niobium (V) oxalate was added to deionized water and stirred until completely dissolved. The Pr, Sr, Fe and Ru nitrates were then added to the solution along with quantitative glycine (mol ratio of metal ion : glycine = 1:2). Secondly, the solution was stirred continuously on a magnetic agitator of 100 °C for 1 h and then heated at 200 °C to obtain sol. Thirdly, heated the sol to 500 °C until the self-combustion is completed. Finally, the collected lightweight powder was calcined in air at 800 °C for 2 h to remove organic residue. For comparison, (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.9Nb0.1O3-δ (PSFN) and (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9FeO3-δ (PSF) were selected as the reference material and prepared by the same route. The as-prepared PSFRN, PSFN and PSF were treated in wet H2 (∼ 3 vol%H2O) at 900 °C for 2 h to obtain R-PSFRN, R-PSFN and R-PSF, respectively.

Single cells with above-mentioned anodes and LSCF-GDC cathode were prepared as follows. A mixture of 50 wt% PSFRN (or PSFN/PSF) with 50 wt% Ce0.9Gd0.1O1.95 (GDC, Ningbo SOFCMAN) and a mixture of 60 wt% La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.8O3 with 40 wt% GDC were combined with a binder (composed of 90 wt% alpha-terpineol and 10 wt% polyvinyl butyral) in a weight ratio of 1:1 to prepare the PSFRN-GDC (and PSFN-GDC/PSF-GDC) anode and LSCF-GDC cathode ink, respectively [15]. La0.8Sr0.2Ga0.83Mg0.17O3-δ (LSGM) electrolyte pellets (∼300 μm) were prepared by dry-pressing method [10]. For the single cells fabrication, the anode ink was screen printed on the LSGM pellets and calcined at 1100 °C for 2 h in air. And the cathode ink was coated using the same way on the other side of the electrolyte pellet and calcined at 1000 °C for 2 h in air. Besides, the platinum ink was screen printed as a 1 mm square mesh pattern on the electrodes and fired at 900 °C for 1 h to obtain the current collectors.

The crystal structure of the synthesized materials was examined using a X-ray Diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8) with Cu-Ka radiation (optical tube voltage = 40 kV, optical tube current = 40 mA, scanning rate = 10 °/min) in the 2θ range of 20−80 °. Micro-structural analyses of the samples were studied by a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Hitachi SU8010) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100 F), equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Axis Ultra DLD-600W) was used to identify the surface chemical states of PSFRN and R-PSFRN.

The single cells were sealed on the top of the alumina tubes using Ag slurry as sealant. Before the electrochemical test, the anodes were treated in wet H2 (∼ 3 vol%H2O, 50 mL min−1) for ∼2 h to achieve a suitable exsolution amount. During the electrochemical tests, the gas flow rate of wet (∼ 3 vol%H2O) H2 and C3H8 were 50 and 20 mL min−1, respectively. When propane was used as fuel, nitrogen of the same flow rate (20 mL min−1) was injected to anode side simultaneously as carrier gas. Cathodes were simply exposed to ambient air. The current-voltage (I–V) curves and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) tests were conducted with a four probe method using an electrochemical workstation (Zennium E4, Zahner). And the AC impedance was measure in the frequency range from 1 MHz to 10 mHz with an amplitude of 10 mV at the open circuit voltage (OCV). Gas-chromatograph was used to identify the composition of the production gas. The microstructure of the single cells after tests was characterized using Hitachi SU8010 scanning electron microscopy.

The crystal structure of the as-prepared (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.8Ru0.1Nb0.1O3-δ (PSFRN), (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.9Nb0.1O3-δ (PSFN) and (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9FeO3-δ (PSF) was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD). As showed in Fig. 1 a, the XRD patterns of PSFRN, PSFN and PSF present typically cubic perovskite structure, which can be assigned to (Pr0.5Sr0.5)FeO2.752-type (ICDD 01−072-6641, Pm-3 m) perovskite phase. The main diffraction of PSFRN slightly shifts to the low angle due to the lager ionic radius of Ru (Ru3+ ∼ 82 pm) than that of Fe (Fe3+ ∼ 69 pm; Fe4+ ∼ 72.5 pm) and Nb (Nb5+ ∼78 pm) [16].

The PSFRN, PSFN and PSF powders were treated in wet H2 at 900 °C for 2 h to yield R-PSFRN, R-PSFN and R-PSF. Fig. 1b indicates three phases in the R-PSFRN: the main cubic perovskite phase with the general formula (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.9-
x Ru x Nb0.1O3-δ, the half-peak width of the (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9Fe0.9-
x Ru x Nb0.1O3-δ is larger than that of the as prepared PSFRN sample, indicating that there may be structural distortion during the reduction process. The other phases are the PrSrFe0.9-
y Ru y Nb0.1O4+δ (RP-PSFRN, corresponding to the Ruddlesden-Popper (RP) type layered structured perovskite SrPrFeO4 (ICDD 00−032-1237)) and Fe0.7Ru0.3 alloy phase (ICDD 04−006-6415, P63/mmc) [17]. The XRD results reflect that the PSFRN is partially transformed into the RP type layer perovskite due to the exsolution of Fe and Ru [18–21]. Besides, the PSFN is partially transformed into the RP type layer perovskite after treatment (Fig. S1). Meanwhile, the major phase of PSF completely transforms from cubic perovskite phase into the Ruddlesden-Popper (RP) perovskite phase (RP-PSF) during the reduction process (Fig. S2), suggesting that PSFRN and PSFN has better stability of phase structure in the reducing atmosphere. Furthermore, the obvious peaks at 44.56˚ in Fig. S1 and S2 indicate that considerable Fe precipitates from the perovskite lattice. After reoxidation, the R-PSFRN reversibly reverted to the original cubic perovskite structure, suggesting the reversible phase transition of PSFRN and R-PSFRN under redox atmosphere.

SEM was applied to investigate the microstructure evolution of the PSFRN, PSFN and PSF during the reduction process. Fig. 2 a shows that the as-prepared PSFRN sample is coral-like and porous with a smooth surface. The lattice fringe spacing is 0.279 nm (Fig. 2b, c), which is consistent with the (110) planes of the PSFRN measured by XRD (Fig. 1a). After being treated in wet H2 at 900 °C for 2 h, a large number of nanoparticles with an average size of about ∼50 nm are uniformly distributed on the surface of R-PSFRN sample (Fig. 2d). The clear grain boundaries between the nanoparticles and the perovskite substrate can be seen from the Fig. 2e, and the nanoparticles possess significant core-shell structure. The d-spacing of the core is 0.225 nm (Fig. 2f), matching the (100) orientation of Fe0.7Ru0.3, which is consistent with the XRD results (Fig. 1b). The shell covered on the surface of the nanoparticles is 2−3 nm with a d-spacing of 0.297 nm.

Correspondingly, after being treated in wet H2 at 900 °C for 2 h, the R-PSF substrate surface appears with sparsely distributed exsolved particles with the average size of about ∼90 nm (Fig. S3b). The low density distribution and large size nanoparticles provide a lower specific surface area for the catalytic reactions, which limits the improvement of catalytic performance. It can be known from the previous research that the exsolution ability of B-site cations can be influence by the reducible elements doping [22–28]. The melting point of metal has an important effect on the size of the nanoparticles. Metals with lower melting point such as Fe, Ni, Co, tend to precipitate into large particles and continue to grow at high temperatures. In contrast, when the higher melting point metal is simultaneously doped in the B site, such as Ru, the particle growth can be suppressed [29]. As seen in Fig. S3d, the exsolved nanoparticles on the surface of R-PSFN are of about ∼75 nm, which is larger than that of the exsolved nanoparticles on the R-PSFRN surface. This result reflects that the exsolved particles can be controlled within the appropriate size range by the formation of FeRu alloy.

The analysis of the EDX elements analysis further revealed the composition of the nanoparticles. The high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) image of the exsolved nanoparticles is shown in Fig. 3 a, in which the element distribution is detected by EDX line scan (Fig. 3b) and EDX surface mapping (Fig. 3c-h). The results show that the nanoparticles are composed of Fe, Ru and O elements, while Pr, Sr and Nb elements are almost undetectable in nanoparticles. Fig. 3b shows that O element is uniformly distributed without segregation on the surface of the nanoparticles. By contrast, the concentration of Ru in the shell is negligible and mainly distributed in the nanoparticle’s core. While the content of Fe increased significantly from shell to core transition region. Fe and O are the main components of the shell, indicating that the shell is an oxide of iron. The mapping results (Fig. 3c-h) also confirm the core-shell structure of the nanoparticle. The formation mechanism of core-shell structure is mainly attributed to the reductive difference between Fe2+/3+ and Ru3+ in the perovskite lattice and the presence of H2O in the wet H2 (∼3 vol% H2O). During the reduction treatment, Fe and Ru atoms migrate from the interior of the lattice to the surface and form nanoparticles of Fe-Ru alloy with Fe segregation in the outermost layer of the nanoparticles. The outermost Fe reacts with H2O to form the FeO x shell layer. To further verify this idea, PSFRN was treated in 5% H2-95 % N2 without H2O. The TEM images of PSFRN after being treated are showed in Fig. S4, and no shell is detected in the exsolved nanoparticles. The FeO x shell is associated with the presence of H2O in the reducing atmosphere, confirming that it was formed during the reduction process.

The change of oxidation state of Fe and Ru elements in PSFRN powder before and after reduction was analyzed by the XPS. The results are shown in Fig. 4 , all spectra have been calibrated with C 1s peaks located at 284.8 eV [15,30]. The Fe 2p3/2 peak in the as prepared PSFRN demonstrates mixed oxidation states of Fe element, including Fe3+ (approximately 710.8 eV) and Fe2+ (approximately 709.8 eV) [31,32]. Meanwhile, the Ru 3p3/2 in the as prepared PSFRN is fitted into Ru3+ (approximately 461.1 eV) [33]. After reduction process, an additional peak located at 706.7 eV is observed in the reduced Fe 2p3/2 spectrum due to the partially exsolution of Fe° (Fig. 4a). The peak ratio of Fe°/(Fe2+ and Fe3+) is 0.05 in the R-PSFRN sample, indicating that only a small part of iron was reduced to metal, while most of the iron cations were arranged in the cubic perovskite and RP layer perovskite phase. Futhermore, a large and intense peak corresponding to the metallic Ru appears in the reduced Ru3p3/2 spectrum with a binding energy of 461.2 eV (Fig. 4b), indicating that substantial ruthenium is reduced to metallic state during the reduction process. The XPS spectra confirmed the presence of the metallic Fe and Ru in the R-PSFRN, which is in agreement with the TEM and EDX analysis results of the exsolved nanoparticles.

To evaluate the electrochemical performance of the R-PSFRN, electrical conductivity measurement, area specific resistance (ASR) measurement and electrochemical performance tests were carried out by a four probe method. Fig. 5 a and b shows the electrical conductivity of R-PSFRN and R-PSF samples in the temperature range of 350−900 °C in wet H2, respectively. With the increase of temperature, the conductivity of R-PSFRN increases rapidly. Besides, the electrical conductivity of the R-PSFRN is two orders of magnitude higher than that of the R-PSF. Since the electrons are conducted by the small polaron hopping along the Fe3+-O-Fe2+ metal-oxide cations chains, the high oxidation state of Nb5+ in the perovskite lattice can strongly hold the oxygen and thus help to keep the electron-hole carriers. Furthermore, the Arrhenius plots show significant slope changes at higher temperatures (Fig. 5c), especially above 575 °C, which may be attributed to the valence changes of B-site cations [34]. The oxygen vacancies formed in the lattice at high temperature induce the reduction of B cations to low valence states, resulting in the different activation energies of the electron hopping along the Fe3+-O-Fe2+ bonds.

The polarization of SOFC anode could be quantitatively characterized by measuring the AC impedance of symmetric cell with R-PSFRN-GDC as electrodes. The results are shown in Fig. 5d, in order to compare the polarization intuitively in the temperature range of 750−900 °C in wet H2, the ohmic resistance obtained from the test is deducted. The area specific resistance (ASR) of R-PSFRN-GDC electrode is 0.13, 0.094, 0.078, 0.067 Ω cm−2 at 750, 800, 850, 900 °C, respectively, which are comparable to that of the conventional Ni-based electrode. In order to simplify the analysis process, the polarization impedance can be studied by equivalent circuit model (Fig. S5). The fitted results contain three main impedance responses, which can be divided into high-frequency impedance (HF), medium-frequency impedance (MF) and low-frequency impedance (LF). In SOFC, the HF and MF is mainly the ion and electron transfer polarization responses of the electrochemical reactions, and the LF is the gas absorption/desorption on the surface of the material and the diffusion response in the electrode. Table S1 shows that the electrochemical polarization response decreases significantly with the increase of temperature, suggesting that the concentration polarization may be the rate-determining step in the high temperature range.

The LSGM supported single cells were tested to evaluate the electrochemical performance of R-PSFRN. Fig. 6 a shows the current-voltage and corresponding power density curves of single cell with R-PSFRN-GDC and R-PSF-GDC as anode using wet H2 (∼ 3 vol% H2O) as fuel and ambient air as oxidant at 800 °C. The corresponding impedance spectra were showed in Fig. 6b. The open circuit voltages (OCV) are 1.085 and 1.067 V for the cells with R-PSFRN-GDC and R-PSF-GDC anode, respectively, which are close to the Nernst theoretical value, indicating that the cells are well sealed. The peak power density (Pmax) of the cell with R-PSFRN-GDC anode is 0.683 W cm−2, while that of the cell with R-PSF-GDC anode is only 0.463 W cm−2, confirming that the active nanoparticles exsolved on the surface have a positive influence on the perovskite anode.

Fig. 6b shows the impedance spectra of the single cells with R-PSFRN-GDC and R-PSF-GDC anode under OCV in wet H2 at 800 °C. The electrochemical polarization resistances (Rp) of the single cells with R-PSFRN-GDC and R-PSF-GDC anode are 0.034 and 0.168 Ω cm−2, respectively. Besides, the electrochemical performance of R-PSFN was also tested. As showed in Fig. S5, the cell with R-PSFN-GDC anode shows a Pmax of 0.490 W cm−2 and Rp of 0.168 Ω cm−2 in wet H2 at 800 °C, which is similar to the cell with R-PSF-GDC anode, suggesting that the improvement of the catalytic ability is mainly due to the FRA@FO nanoparticles. Furthermore, the single cell with R-PSFRN-GDC anode has delivered a stable power output under a constant loading current density of 1 A cm−2 at 800 °C (Fig. S6), indicating that the perovskite can maintain a continuous output in the reducing atmosphere.

When the fuel is switched to the wet C3H8 (50 % C3H8-50 % N2), Fig. 7 a shows the current-voltage and power density curves of single cell with R-PSFRN-GDC and R-PSF-GDC as anode at 800 °C. The peak power density (Pmax) of the cell with R-PSFRN-GDC anode is 0.537 W cm−2, while that of the cell with R-PSF-GDC anode is only 0.110 W cm−2. The corresponding impedance spectra are showed in Fig. 7b. The Rp of the single cells with R-PSFRN-GDC and R-PSF-GDC anode are 0.113 and 0.332 Ω cm−2, respectively, indicating R-PSFRN-GDC has a better catalytic activity toward the electrochemical oxidation of C3H8. In addition, the cell with R-PSFN-GDC anode shows Pmax of 0.411 W cm−2 and Rp of 0.288 Ω cm−2 in wet C3H8 at 800 °C(Fig. S7), suggesting the FRA@FO nanoparticles play the key role in C3H8 catalysis.

The Pmax of the cell with R-PSFRN-GDC anode is 0.762, 0.677, 0.537, 0.374 W cm−2 at 900, 850, 800, 750 °C, respectively (Fig. 7c), and the corresponding Rp increases from 0.045 Ω cm−2 at 900 °C to 0.198 Ω cm−2 at 750 °C (Fig. 7d). In order to evaluate the catalytic activity of R-PSFRN toward C3H8 conversion, the composition of production gas was examined by a gas-chromatograph. Fig. 7e shows that the production gas consists of CH4, C3H6, H2, C2H4, CO, CO2 and the residue C3H8. The conversion of C3H8 is 99.46 %, 98.18 %, 96.71 %, 91.12 % at 900, 850, 800, 750 °C, respectively. At high temperature, the main products are CH4 and H2, along with negligible C3H6. Nevertheless, the percentage of C3H6 increases with the temperature drop and changes to 18.02 % at 750 °C, demonstrating that the cell has a better ability to co-generate C3H6 and electricity at relatively low operating temperature.

Moreover, a stability test for 100 h under a current density of 0.15 A cm−2 was carried out under 750 °C. As shown in Fig. 7f, the voltage tends to stabilize after a brief attenuation and remains around 0.75 V in the subsequent test. Although at a relatively low temperature, the single cell maintains a continuous electrochemical conversion of hydrocarbon fuels. Fig. 7g and h show the microstructure of the R-PSFRN-GDC anode after durability test. The anode still maintains a coral-like porous structure, and there is no obvious carbon particle or fiber on the surface of the anode. Furthermore, the nanoparticles exsolved on the surface maintain ∼50 nm after test without agglomeration, indicating that the R-PSFRN exhibits a good stability in the hydrocarbon fuels.

The cells with R-PSFRN-GDC anode show high performance with both H2 and C3H8 as fuel. Based on the above mention results and the understanding of the exsolved core-shell nanoparticles, the effects of the Ru and Nb dopant can be summarized as below. First of all, the FRA@FO nanoparticles formed on the R-PSFRN surface are small and dense, providing a large number of active sites for electrochemical reactions. In addition, Nb with high valence states have strong attraction to the surrounding oxygen ions and maintain structural stability during the long-term operation.

In the perovskite anode, the fuel oxidation may follow the Mars-van Krevalen mechanism [35,36], which presents the oxidation of fuel is carried out by the interaction between adsorbed substances and lattice oxygen. The oxidation of fuel is carried out through the following steps: (1) H2 and C3H8 initially undergo chemisorption on the surface of catalyst, and dissociate into H(ad) and CH x
(ad). (2) The H(ad) and CH x
(ad) react with lattice oxygen at the active sites (B n
+-O-B n
+), yielding H2O and CO2, forming oxygen vacancies (B(
n
−1)+-
V O
∙ ∙
-B(
n
−1)+) and releasing electrons into the external circuit. (3) Oxygen ions generated in cathode migrate to anode and replenish oxygen vacancies for another cycle. Furthermore, we hypothesized and depicted the fuel catalytic mechanism of the core-shell nanoparticle in Fig. 8 . At the elevated temperature, the oxygen ions in the FeO x are easy to combine with the adsorbed substances, which can activate the surface adsorbed hydrogen [37–39].Then, the lattice oxygen ions in FeO x binds to H(ad)/CH x
(ad) to form an intermediate, which is the rate determination step for the fuel oxidation process. Meanwhile, the electrons produced in the process are transmitted through the Fe0.7Ru0.3 core to the perovskite substrate. Different from the uniform exsolved nanoparticles prepared by the conventional in situ exsolution that mainly promote the adsorption and dissociation of the fuel, the FRA@FO can also participate in the rate determination step of the fuel oxidation reactions, greatly broadening the TPB of electrochemical reactions.

The Ru and Nb Co-doped (Pr0.5Sr0.5)0.9FeO3-
δ perovskite anode was studied in this work. Upon exposed in the reducing atmosphere at high temperature, Fe and Ru exsolved from PSFRN, resulting in the formation of the FRA@FO nanoparticles with an average size of about ∼50 nm. The nanoparticles composed of Fe0.7Ru0.3 core and FeO x shell show a good electrochemical catalytic toward H2 and C3H8. The Pmax of the single cell with R-PSFRN-GDC anode and LSGM electrolyte reached 0.683 W cm−2 at 800 °C using wet H2 as fuel. The same cell fed with wet C3H8 exhibited a Pmax of 0.762, 0.677, 0.537, 0.374 W cm−2 at 900, 850, 800, 750 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the core-shell structure nanoparticles firmly anchored on the perovskite substrate exhibited a high stability in the durability tests with C3H8 as fuel.

Mingxia Qin: Conceptualization, Methodology, Resources, Investigation, Writing - original draft, Project administration. Yu Xiao: Validation, Formal analysis, Writing - review & editing, Project administration. Hongyu Yang: Investigation, Validation. Ting Tan: Visualization. Ziming Wang: Data curation. Xinming Fan: Supervision, Writing - review & editing. Chenghao Yang: Supervision, Funding acquisition, Writing - review & editing.
